case_name: Logendranath Jha and others v. Polai Lal Biswas

facts.text: This is an appeal by special leave from an order of the High Court of Judicature at Patna setting aside an order of acquittal of the appellants by the Sessions Judge, Purnea, and directing their retrial.

anchor.surface_text: Patanjali Sastri, J. This is an appeal by special leave from an order of the High Court of Judicature at Patna setting aside an order of acquittal of the appellants by the Sessions Judge, Purnea, and directing their retrial.

facts.text: The appellants were prosecuted for alleged offences under sections 147, 148, 323, 324, 326, 302 and 302/149 of the Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants were prosecuted for alleged offences under sections 147, 148, 323, 324, 326, 302 and 302/149 of the Indian Penal Code at the instance of one Polai Lal Biswas who lodged a companyplaint against them before the police.

facts.text: Polai Lal Biswas lodged a complaint against the appellants before the police.

anchor.surface_text: at the instance of one Polai Lal Biswas who lodged a companyplaint against them before the police. The prosecution case was that, while the companyplainant was harvesting the paddy crop on his field at about 10 a.m. on 29th November, 1949,

facts.text: While the complainant was harvesting the paddy crop on his field at about 10 a.m. on 29th November, 1949, a mob of about fifty persons came on to the field armed with ballams, lathis and other weapons.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution case was that, while the companyplainant was harvesting the paddy crop on his field at about 10 a.m. on 29th November, 1949, a mob of about fifty persons came on to the field armed with ballams, lathis and other weapons and that the first appellant Logendranath Jha, who was leading the mob,

facts.text: The first appellant Logendranath Jha was leading the mob.

anchor.surface_text: and that the first appellant Logendranath Jha, who was leading the mob, demanded a settlement of all outstanding disputes with the companyplainant and said he would number allow the paddy to be removed unless the disputes were settled.

facts.text: Logendranath Jha demanded a settlement of all outstanding disputes with the complainant and said he would not allow the paddy to be removed unless the disputes were settled.

anchor.surface_text: demanded a settlement of all outstanding disputes with the companyplainant and said he would number allow the paddy to be removed unless the disputes were settled. An altercation followed as a result of which Logendra ordered an assault by his men.

facts.text: Logendra and one of his men, Harihar, gave ballam blows to one of the labourers, Kangali, who fell down and died on the spot.

anchor.surface_text: Then Logendra and one of his men, Harihar, gave ballam blows to one of the abourers, Kangali, who fell down and died on the spot. Information was given to the police who investigated the case and submitted the charge-sheet.

facts.text: Information was given to the police who investigated the case and submitted the charge-sheet.

anchor.surface_text: Information was given to the police who investigated the case and submitted the charge-sheet. The companymitting Magistrate found that a prima facie case was made out and companymitted the appellants to the Court of Sessions for trial.

facts.text: The committing Magistrate found that a prima facie case was made out and committed the appellants to the Court of Sessions for trial.

anchor.surface_text: The companymitting Magistrate found that a prima facie case was made out and companymitted the appellants to the Court of Sessions for trial. The appellants pleaded number guilty alleging inter alia, that Mohender and Debender, the brothers of Logendra  appellants 2 and 3  were number present in the village of Dandkhora with which they had numberconcern,

facts.text: Appellants pleaded not guilty.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants pleaded number guilty alleging inter alia, that Mohender and Debender, the brothers of Logendra  appellants 2 and 3  were number present in the village of Dandkhora with which they had numberconcern,

facts.text: Mohender and Debender, brothers of Logendra (appellants 2 and 3), were not present in the village of Dandkhora with which they had no concern, as all lands there allotted to Logendra at previous partition.

anchor.surface_text: that Mohender and Debender, the brothers of Logendra  appellants 2 and 3  were number present in the village of Dandkhora with which they had numberconcern, as all the lands in that village had been allotted to Logendra at a previous partition, that Logendra himself was number in the village at the time of the occurrence but arrived soon after

facts.text: Logendra himself was not in the village at the time of the occurrence but arrived soon after and was dragged to the place at the instance of his enemies and placed under arrest by the Assistant Sub-Inspector of Police.

anchor.surface_text: that Logendra himself was number in the village at the time of the occurrence but arrived soon after and was dragged to the place at the instance of his enemies in the village and was placed under arrest by the Assistant Sub-Inspector of Police who had arrived there previously.

facts.text: There were two factions in the village, one led by Harimohan, a relation of the complainant, and the other by Logendra, with numerous revenue and criminal proceedings and long-standing enmity between the families.

anchor.surface_text: It was also alleged that there were two factions in the village, one of which was led by one Harimohan, a relation of the companyplainant, and the other by Logendra and there had been numerous revenue and criminal proceedings and long-standing enemity between the families of these leaders as a result of which this false case was foisted upon the appellants.

facts.text: The Sessions Judge found that the existence of factions as alleged by the appellants was true.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sessions Judge examined the evidence in great detail and found that the existence of factions as alleged by the appellants was true.

facts.text: The Sessions Judge found that the appellants' plea of alibi was not satisfactorily made out.

anchor.surface_text: He found, however, that the appellants plea of alibi was number satisfactorily made out, but the truth of the prosecution, he proceeded to observe, cannot be judged by the falsehood of the defence number can the prosecution derive its strength from the weakness of the defence.

facts.text: The Sessions Judge disbelieved the prosecution story that Polai had taken the lands on batai settlement from his maternal grandmother Parasmani or uncles and was harvesting the paddy crop.

anchor.surface_text: He, therefore, disbelieved the whole story that Polai had taken the lands of his grandmother or his uncles as bataidar for cultivation and that he was engaged in harvesting the paddy crop on the lands at the time of the occurrence. This false story, in his opinion, vitally affected the prosecution case regarding the alleged manner of the occurrence.

facts.text: Polai was 19 years old, unmarried, living with his grandmother Parasmani who brought him up from childhood.

anchor.surface_text: Polai, who was alleged to have taken the land on batai settlement from his own maternal grandmother Parasmani who brought him up from his childhood, was only 19 years old and unmarried and was still living with his grandmother.

facts.text: The learned Sessions Judge acquitted the appellants of all the charges.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge accordingly acquitted the appellants of all the charges framed against them. Against that order the companyplainant Polai preferred a revision petition to the High Court under section 439 of the Criminal Procedure Code.

facts.text: Polai preferred a revision petition to the High Court under section 439 of the Criminal Procedure Code against the acquittal order.

anchor.surface_text: Against that order the companyplainant Polai preferred a revision petition to the High Court under section 439 of the Criminal Procedure Code. The learned Judge who heard the petition reviewed the evidence at some length and came to the companyclusion that the judgment of the learned Sessions Judge companyld number be allowed to stand as the acquittal of the appellants was perverse.

facts.text: The High Court set aside the acquittal as perverse and directed retrial.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge who heard the petition reviewed the evidence at some length and came to the companyclusion that the judgment of the learned Sessions Judge companyld number be allowed to stand as the acquittal of the appellants was perverse.

facts.text: The Supreme Court is hearing an appeal by special leave against the High Court order.

facts.text: High Court directed re-trial without convicting the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellants Mr. Sinha raised two contentions. In the first place, he submitted that having regard to section 417 of the Criminal Procedure Code which provides for an appeal to the High Court from an order of acquittal only at the instance of the Government, a revision petition under section 439 at the instance of a private party was incompetent

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the learned Judge in the High Court did not properly appreciate the scope of inquiry in revision against an order of acquittal. Though sub-section 1 of section 439 authorises the High Court to exercise, in its discretion, any of the powers conferred on a court of appeal by section 423, sub-section 4 specifically excludes

arguments.claim: High Court cannot re-appraise evidence and reverse findings of fact merely by characterising trial court judgment as perverse

anchor.surface_text: By merely characterising the judgment of the trial Court as perverse and lacking in perspective, the High Court cannot reverse pure findings of fact based on the trial Courts appreciation of the evidence in the case.

arguments.claim: High Court loaded the dice against appellants by strong opinions on evidence while ordering retrial, prejudicing fair trial

But there can be little doubt that he loaded the dice against the appellants

holdings.text: The learned Judge in the High Court did not properly appreciate the scope of inquiry in revision against an order of acquittal.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the learned Judge in the High Court did not properly appreciate the scope of inquiry in revision against an order of acquittal. Though sub-section  1  of section 439 authorises the High Court to exercise,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sub-section (1) of s.439 allows exercise of appellate powers under s.423 but sub-section (4) excludes power to convert acquittal into conviction, limiting scope in private revisions against acquittal.

holdings.text: In dealing with a revision petition by a private party against an order of acquittal, the High Court could not, in the absence of any error on a point of law, re-appraise the evidence and reverse the findings of facts on which the acquittal was based.

anchor.surface_text: This does not mean that in dealing with a revision petition by a private party against an order of acquittal, the High Court could in the absence of any error on a point of law re-appraise the evidence and reverse the findings of facts on which the acquittal was based, provided only it stopped short of finding the accused guilty and passing sentence on him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory limit under s.439(4) prevents full appellate re-appraisal of facts in revision by private party; must stop short of conviction.

holdings.text: By merely characterising the judgment of the trial Court as perverse and lacking in perspective, the High Court cannot reverse pure findings of fact based on the trial Court's appreciation of the evidence in the case.

anchor.surface_text: By merely characterising the judgment of the trial Court as perverse and lacking in perspective, the High Court cannot reverse pure findings of fact based on the trial Courts appreciation of the evidence in the case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mere labelling as perverse does not suffice to overturn factual findings without error of law; High Court improperly did so here.

holdings.text: The learned Judge formally complied with sub-section (4) by directing only a re-trial without convicting but loaded the dice against the appellants by strong expressions of opinion on evidence and credibility.

anchor.surface_text: No doubt, the learned Judge formally complied with sub-section  4  by directing only a re-trial of the appellants without convicting them, and warned that the courts retrying the case should not be influenced by any expression of opinion contained in his judgment. But there can be little doubt that he loaded the dice against the appellants

holdings.reasoning_summary: Strong views on prosecution evidence and witness credibility while ordering retrial prejudice fair trial prospects for accused.
